datafield.subfield: William D. Ford represented Michigan's Fifteenth Congressional District for thirty years, from 1964 to 1994.

Born August 6, 1927 in Detroit, Ford served in the Navy from 1944 to 1946, then attended Nebraska State Teachers College (1946), Wayne State University (1947-1948), and the University of Denver, from which he received a Bachelor of Science degree in 1949, and a Juris Doctor degree in 1951.

Ford held political positions at the local level in Wayne County before being elected to the Michigan State Senate in 1962. When the Fifteenth District was created in 1964, he had the support of state Democratic leaders to take the seat. He was reelected until his retirement in 1994.

In Congress, Ford sat on the Education and Labor Committee for his entire congressional career, and became its chairman in 1991. The committee brought together Ford's two main interests, and he concentrated on building a reputation for handling education and labor legislation. He is perhaps best known for his work on college aid programs which targeted middle class voters, and he was also a proponent of vocational education.

On labor issues, Ford worked for fourteen years to pass a plant-closure notification bill, which became law in 1987 after intense negotiation and compromise by Ford. Ford also served as chairman of the Post Office and Civil Service Committee, and regularly voted in favor of pay increases for federal employees and legislators. In 1994, Ford chose not to run for office again, and retired from Congress to work for a Washington law firm.

The William D. Ford papers are divided into seven series: Subject Files, Legislative Files, Committee Files, Campaign Material, Public Relations, Photographs, and Visual Material. The collection is primarily an office file which documents Ford's activities as a local representative, federal legislator and politician. Constituents' opinions and concerns are represented as well, particularly in the correspondence and questionnaire response files.

Subject files (78 linear feet; 1965-1995) include correspondence from constituents, memoranda with staff, questionnaires and background material. The files are arranged chronologically by year, and then alphabetically by topic within each year. The original office filing systems have been maintained; files dating from 1965 to 1979 are listed by slightly idiosyncratic folder headings,

while files dating from 1980 to 1995 are arranged using standardized subject headings, followed by more detailed subheadings. Most of the constituent correspondence is arranged by topic, and major controversies of the time are well represented, including the Vietnam War, amnesty for draft dodgers, busing, Watergate, economic issues and abortion.

Legislative Files (15 linear feet; 1965-1980) consist of bills, correspondence, memoranda and clippings. They are arranged chronologically by year, and within each year, alphabetically by name of the committee which was responsible for the legislation.

Committee Files (30 linear feet; 1969-1994) are divided into three subseries: Education and Labor Committee, Post Office and Civil Service Committee (POCS), and Staff Files: Ross Eisenbrey. This series documents Ford's legislative responsibilities on the two House committees with which he was most actively involved. Bills, correspondence, briefing notes and memoranda provide a sesne of his working relationships with colleagues, committee staff, and lobbyists.

Ford's increasingly influential standing on these committees is reflected in the greater size and substance of the committee files in the 1990s, particularly once he became chairman of the Education and Labor committee. The bulk of information about Ford's role in legislating student aid programs is in the Post-Secondary Education Subcommittee files.

Ross Eisenbrey was Ford's senior legislative aide between 1979 and 1988. His files include correspondence and briefing notes pertaining to the Education and Labor and POCS committees, and have been maintained as a separate subseries.

Campaign Material (6 linear feet; 1962-1990) contains correspondence, press releases, fliers and memoranda for each of Ford's election campaigns, from his run for Michigan State Senate in 1962 to his 1990 congressional campaign. The series documents the increasing sophistication of both campaigning and fundraising methods from the 1960s to the 1990s.

Of particular interest is "A Survey of Voter Attitudes in the Fifteenth Congressional District of Michigan", commissioned by Ford in 1980 as an analysis of the "Reagan Democrat" phenomenon in the district.

Another significant part of the series are the Gerald Carlson Information files. Carlson was a "white rights" candidate with connections to the American Nazi Party, who ran against Ford in the early 1980s. FOrd's staff collected political material and information about Carlson, as well as tapes of his radio advertisements.
Public Relations (10 linear feet; 1955-1994) includes speech materials, press releases, newsclippings, schedules, and biographical information about Ford.

Visual Material (7 linear feet; 1955-1994) consists of photographs and videotapes. Photographs are arranged in chronological order, and include pictures of virtually all the major events of Ford's political career. There are also photographs of Ford with state and national political figures. Videotapes are mainly of Ford's monthly TV program.
